revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Infobox comics creator | name = Ted Key | image = Tedkeybooth.jpg | caption = Ted Key with actress [[Shirley Booth]]; the latter is outfitted in the maid's uniform she wore on television as ''[[Hazel (comic strip)|Hazel]].'' | birth_name = Theodore Keyser | birth_date = {{Birth date|1912|8|25}} | birth_place = [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], [[California]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age |2008|5|3|1912|8|25}} | death_place = [[Tredyffrin Township, Pennsylvania|Tredyffrin]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | area = | alias = | signature = | notable works = ''[[Hazel (comic strip)|Hazel]]'' | awards = 1977 [[National Cartoonists Society]] Newspaper Panel Award }} '''Ted Key''' (born '''Theodore Keyser'''; August 25, 1912 – May 3, 2008),<ref name=nyt>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/06/arts/design/06key.html?_r=1&adxnnl=1&oref=slogin&ref=obituaries&adxnnlx=1210255335-eI4U3i0bNHL9FkaFQKLVvA Weber, Bruce. "Ted Key, 95, Creator of 'Hazel' Cartoon, Is Dead"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 8, 2008</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[cartoonist]] and writer. He is best known as the creator of the cartoon panel ''[[Hazel (comic strip)|Hazel]]'', which was later the basis for a [[Hazel (TV series)|television series of the same name]], and also the creator of ''[[Mister Peabody|Peabody's Improbable History]]''.
==College to cartoons== Born in [[Fresno, California]], Key was the son of [[Latvia]]n immigrant Simon Keyser, who had changed his name from Katseff to Keyser, and then to "Key" during [[World War I]].<ref name=nyt/> Though his family thereafter went by Key, Theodore Keyser did not legally adopt the name until the 1950s.<ref name=nyt /> Attending the [[University of California, Berkeley]], Key became the art editor of the student newspaper, ''[[The Daily Californian]]'', and was associate editor of the campus humor magazine, the ''[[California Pelican (magazine)|California Pelican]]''<ref name=king>
{{cite web| last =King Features Syndicate| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =''Hazel'' by Ted Key: About the Cartoonist| work =| publisher =| date =| url =http://www.kingfeatures.com/features/comics/hazel/bioMaina.htm| doi =| accessdate =2008-05-05| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081121115651/http://www.kingfeatures.com/features/comics/hazel/bioMaina.htm| archivedate =2008-11-21| df =}}</ref> and was a member of the [[Pi Lambda Phi]] [[fraternity]].<ref>Membership Directory, 2010, Pi Lambda Phi Inc.</ref> After graduating from college in 1933, Key relocated to [[New York City]], where he published cartoons and illustrations in a number of periodicals, including ''[[Better Homes and Gardens (magazine)|Better Homes and Gardens]]'', ''[[Collier's]]'', ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[Ladies' Home Journal]]'', ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'', ''[[McCall's]]'', ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'', ''[[TV Guide]]'', ''[[Mademoiselle (magazine)|Mademoiselle]]'', ''[[Look (American magazine)|Look]]'' and ''Judge.'' Key also worked as associate editor of ''Judge'' in 1937.
==''Hazel''== [[image:Hazelbook46.jpg|thumb]] Key's most famous creation, the single-panel ''Hazel'', about a wry and bossy household maid, came to Key in 1943 in a dream that he drew the next morning and sent to ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]'', where it was accepted and began running regularly.<ref name=nyt /> He soon afterward gave the character a name and employment at the Baxter household. In 2008, the cartoonist's son, Peter Key, said, "He picked the name Hazel out of the air, but there was an editor at ''The Post'' who had a sister named Hazel. She thought her brother came up with the name, and she didnâ€™t speak to him for two years."<ref name=nyt />
The cartoon ran until the weekly magazine ceased publication in 1969. ''Hazel'' was then picked up for newspaper syndication by [[King Features Syndicate]].<ref name=toonopedia-hazel>[http://toonopedia.com/hazel.htm Hazel] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/66tVx9fSn?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/hazel.htm Archived] from the original on April 13, 2012.</ref> With the increased output of six cartoons a week, Key hired veteran gag cartoonist [[Stan Fine]] to lend a hand.
Key later adapted his comic panel into the television show ''[[Hazel (TV series)|Hazel]]'', starring [[Shirley Booth]] as the titular maid. It ran from 1961 to 1964 on [[NBC]]; for its final 1965 season, the show switched to [[CBS]]. Key continued to draw the strip until his retirement in 1993.<ref>{{cite web| last =Evanier| first =Mark| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Ted Key, R.I.P.| work =| publisher =P.O.V. Online: News from Me (column)| date =May 5, 2008<!--, 10:48 a.m. PT -->| url =http://www.newsfromme.com/archives/2008_05_05.html#015174| format =| doi =| accessdate =2008-05-05| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080511095449/http://www.newsfromme.com/archives/2008_05_05.html#015174| archivedate =May 11, 2008| df =}}</ref> King Features reprints panels in over 50 newspapers as of 2008.<ref name=king />
==Films and television== Key's other work in the comics field includes ''Diz and Liz'', a two-page feature that ran in ''[[Jack and Jill (magazine)|Jack and Jill]]'' magazine from 1961 to 1972, as well as creating the segment ''[[Mister Peabody|Peabody's Improbable History]]'' for producer [[Jay Ward]]'s [[animated television series]] ''[[The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last = Markstein | first = Don | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Toonopedia: "Peabody's Improbable History" | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.toonopedia.com/peabody.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-05 }}</ref> Key also provided illustrations for the long-running "Positive Attitude" series of motivational pamphlets and posters, published biweekly by Economics Press Inc. from the 1960s to the 1980s.<ref>{{cite web | last = TedKey.com | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = (Official site) | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.tedkey.com/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-05}}</ref>
==Radio== Key also wrote [[radio drama|radio plays]] during the 1930s and 1940s. His radio drama, ''The Clinic'', broadcast on NBC, was chosen for Max Wylie's ''Best Broadcasts of 1939-40'' anthology.
==Films and books== He was the screenwriter for three [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]] films (''[[The Cat from Outer Space]]'', ''[[Million Dollar Duck]]'' and ''[[Gus (1976 film)|Gus]]''), and he created several classic children's books, including ''Phyllis'' and ''The Biggest Dog in the World'' (later adapted into the film ''[[Digby, the Biggest Dog in the World]]'').<ref name=pbj>{{Cite news | last = Unbylined | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Creator of Hazel, motivational posters Ted Key dies at 95 | newspaper = Philadelphia Business Journal | pages = | year = | date = May 5, 2008 | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/stories/2008/05/05/daily10.html | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref>
During World War II, Key served with the [[U.S. Army]] from 1943 to 1946, primarily in [[public relations]], where he wrote a play aimed at recruiting women into military service.<ref name=nyt/> Key retired in 1993, but King Features continued to syndicate ''Hazel'' using material he had prepared for his retirement. ''Hazel'' still runs today in some 50 newspapers.
Diagnosed with [[bladder cancer]] in late 2006, Key suffered a stroke in September 2007. He was 95 at the time of his death in [[Tredyffrin Township, Pennsylvania|Tredyffrin Township]], [[Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Lentz | first = Bob | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Cartoonist Ted Key, creator of 'Hazel' comic, dies at 95 | work = | publisher = Associated Press via Yahoo! News | date = May 5, 2008<!--, 9:08 p.m. ET -->| format = | doi =}}</ref> Key was married twice; his first wife, Anne, died in 1984, and Key was survived by second wife Bonnie and by three sons: Stephen, David and Peter.<ref name=pbj />
==Awards== In 1977, Key received the [[National Cartoonists Society]] Newspaper Panel Award for his work on ''Hazel''.<ref>{{cite web | last = National Cartoonists Society | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Newspaper Panel | work = | publisher = | date = May 5, 2008<!--, 10:48 a.m. ET -->| url = http://www.reuben.org/ncs/archive/divisions/panels.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-05-05 }}</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Many Happy Returns'' (1951) *''So'm I'' (1954) *''Fasten Your Seat Belts!: A New Album of Cartoons'' (1956) *''Phyllis'' (1957) *''The Biggest Dog in the World'' (1960) *''Ted Key's Diz and Liz'' (1966) *''The Cat From Outer Space'' (1978) *''Love Is the Reason for It All: The Shirley Booth Story'' (Foreword, plus information on ''Hazel'', 2008)
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name | id=0450774 | name=Ted Key}} *[http://ead.dartmouth.edu/html/ml81.html Papers of Harry Ackerman] *[http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/k/key_t.htm Ted Key Papers 1942-2008] at Syracuse University (primary source material)
